div.head: Question 65 [English Translation of Balliol 246 Transcription]
Whether the eternal love of God is possible for man?
div.p: Whether the eternal love of God is possible for man?

It was argued that not because no man is able to be certain that God eternally loves them, therefore. Consequence is clear because the security that this will be so is included in the eternal love of God according to
Augustinum, De trinitate
and through
Anselmum, De casu dyaboli XXX . The antecedent is proved because if someone is able to have security of this type this would be beyond the limits of a creature insomuch that God would not be able to annihlate him, which is inconvenient. I prove because Petrus is for example is such a person who has this kind of security, and he argues this proposition, it is possible that God will annihilate the punishment The proof is that from this the impossible follow. For the proof follows, God will annihilate the punishment, therefore he will erroneously think that he will eternally have this love, therefore God who made him thus to think this deceives him, therefore the Truth deceives someone, which is impossible and against
Augustine in 83 questions question 14
In opposition is the catholic faith.

In this question there is not difficult hiding for the theologian, for it happens that the ultimate supernatural end of man is the clear enjoyment of the divine essence in itself in which the highest possible beatitude exists, as
Anselm says in 2 Cur Deus homo, in the beginning ,
that the natural creature or nature has been made just by God, so that while enjoying him he will be blessed ought not to be denied
Anselm, Cur Deus Homo, I, c. 1
. And
Monologion 76
proves that God to the rational creature loving God as he ought gives as a reward God himself, so that such a creature may enjoy God without end is most foolish to doubt.

To the argument in the opposition (which has made much deformity while not having much meaning unless the following, how there is security in beatitude), it should be said that this proposition, Peter is secure about his eternal beatitude, is able to be explained in two ways.
First Peter believes without any doubt that he will always be blessed and thus he will be in the truth of the matter.

In another mode thus, Peter believes without any doubt that he will always be bless and thus he will be and it is impossible that it is otherwise.
All the blessed have the first type of security from their beatitude, they do not have the second nor is some creature able to have it because if such adhesion or estimation were had, then the creature would be deceived about the fact that it is impossible that they are not blessed, since every creature as long as it is is freely conserved by God by a dependence which is not able to be resolved. Whence this, today God conserves freely the soul of Christ, just as he ever did. From this the following conclusions should be conceded.
This is contingent, Peter was blessed and is true and always was true.

Similarly, this is contingent, the soul of Christ will be blessed according to one life just as it was elsewhere declared because if these propositions and similar necessary things are explained, then they are explained through propositions, some of which are contingent.

And when in the end of the argument it is shown
that this is impossible, that God will annihilate Peter, because from this the impossible follows, for it follows that God will annihilate Peter, therefore Peter erred, therefore God deceived him, the consequent is false, and the consequence is from Augustine.

To the same is say three things. In the first place that the first consequence validates nothing, God will annihilate Peter, therefore Peter erroneously thins his beatitude will always be, it is necessary to add some proposition and then this copulative will be one where the antecedent is sufficient for this consequent. Whence this consequence should be conceded, God will annihilate Peter and Peter thought that he would be and will be forever, therefore Peter erred and was deceived.

In the second place, I say to this argument that this second consequence is valid, Peter erred, therefore God deceived him as a partial cause. I prove this is the following way, if Peter errered, the there was some erroneous knowledge in the soul of Peter. But every thing which every was in the soul of Peter was from God as an efficient cause, therefore God caused this error. But this is to deceive, therefore God deceived him, for in this way we say, he deceived me, that is he caused in me an erroneous estimation. In the same way about Socrates and about anything which coexists with error in us.

In the third place, these days this term to mislead or to deceive etc is understood both properly and improperly, when properly it is explained as the saying for the causing of the error, when improperly for the vicious and disordered causing of error, and in this way God is not able to deceive. But the consequence of
Augustine to the mind of the angeli, de 83 questions, 14
thus
if Christ deceived by showing the disciples a phantasm in the place of a body, then Christ was not the truth
Xxx . And this consequence is valid and both the antecedent and the consequent are impossible. And through this is clear the distinction of
Blessed Augustine in heaven from De Genese, question 9 53, where he says how God deceived through bad angels and through bad men, but not through good nor immediately through himself, and there he understands deception for inordinate deception.
